text: let's take a look back for a second and
see how we got here 13 reasons why
season 1 brought us this idea of
understanding the consequences of your
actions when you make fun of that guy or
you spread rumors about that girl like
you never really know how far it can go
and where it's all going to end up
season 2 takes us into the courtroom
where Jessica is trying to put Brice in
jail for what he did to her
and as we come to find out Hannah Baker
and who knows how many other girls in
school the undercurrent of this story is
that everyone knew what Bryce was doing
but because of some kind of bro code or
sports jock privilege or whatever you
want to call it no one spoke up until
now season 2 also ends with Bryce
getting basically no punishment
whatsoever and so at the time it seems
like all these girls sharing their
stories was for nothing
and this brings us to season 3 where
Bryce is found murdered and given the
circumstances all the main characters
are suspects throughout the third season
the show keeps asking us this question
how far is too far for redemption as is
typical for this show we keep flashing
back and forth between the past and the
present learning all the reasons why
characters did what it did or why they
think a certain way now during these
flashbacks we get to know a very
different Bryce than what we've seen
pretty much the entire show up to this
point we've seen the rich popular kid
who did whatever he wanted but here he
is trying to make amends for his actions
he works to fix his relationship with
his mom he offers to help Tyler with
what Monty did to him in season two he
goes to therapy and tries to really
understand what it is he did to so many
people but every time he tries to do
what he thinks is the right thing the
world seems to never let him be anything
more than what he already is and so in
the present day when his body's found at
the bottom of a river the characters and
by extension us are all left to wonder
if given enough time and effort he could
have actually ever redeemed himself
again the question is how far is too far
for redemption
so in concept the third season of 13
reasons why is the sort of experiment I
guess in humanizing the people we would
otherwise just write off as horrible
monsters which seems like an odd choice
in the world of today when we constantly
hear about Bryce walkers in Hollywood
the games industry companies politics
seemingly everywhere and as has become
the norm for this show thirteen reasons
why still doesn't seem like it knows
what it really wants to be the show
calls itself a realistic portrayal of
real teen issues today which is great
but it also wants to be a typically
exaggerated overly dramatic look
an adult thirtysomethings who were still
in high school for some reason one big
example of this was the ending in the
final episode we learned that Alex was
the one who threw Bryce into the river
causing him to drown so all of the main
characters come together with an
elaborate lie to pin the murder on Monty
so that way Tyler can get some justice
for what happened to him and Monty's a
jerk anyway so hey who cares right now
as a team drama this is fun and exciting
to watch how they plant the evidence and
trick the police and getting to watch it
all play out the problem is this goes
against everything this show was about
up to this point throughout the entire
run but especially the third season the
main theme has always been about
uncovering the truth what really
happened on those tapes
what did Bryce Walker really do if we
take a look at Jessica for example her
main motivation throughout the whole
season was about fighting against sports
jocks who defend and life with their
friends even when they know what they're
doing is wrong she makes it very clear
that she wants people to own up to and
pay for their actions and just because
someone is your friend or your bro or
whatever doesn't make them immune but
then at the very end of the show Jessica
does exactly that she lies for and
defends Alex even though he murdered
Bryce because Alex and Jessica are
friends so Jessica's entire character
arc is basically almost meaningless
everything she was fighting for
everything she believed or said she
believed turns out to be nothing when
she's put in the same situation now
maybe that was supposed to be the point
maybe we're supposed to see that good
and bad are always relative and it's all
about context or something like that but
if that's the case then what's the point
of anything in the show another problem
that I and seemingly everyone else had
was the new character on now
fundamentally I think having a new kid
at school who observes everything from
the outside with a sort of objective
point of view is a great idea but Ani is
the most bafflingly ridiculous character
I've seen in quite a while her main role
is to let us into Bryce's life because
her mom works as his new family
caretaker so ani and Bryce live in the
same house and they interact with each
other rather often over the drawn out 13
episodes of the show we learned exactly
nothing about ahni's character we get no
backstory no real depth of any kind
she just exists to be slightly annoying
all the time by the end of the season
she becomes this almost comically
super-powered all-knowing omnipresence
who can just somehow be anywhere at any
time but I guess my biggest issue and
what I think is the biggest problem with
13 reasons why season 3
particular but really any show like this
is by its very nature it glorifies or
glamorizes the idea of going through a
traumatic experience now it doesn't do
this directly but what becomes very
apparent in this season is the only
thing interesting about most of these
kids is how flawed and messed up their
lives are every one is defined by the
worst thing that happened to them so
once you remove their various traumas or
issues or addictions or whatever there's
almost nothing left to care about and so
the whole show has this I assume
unintentional theme that having these
heavy issues and going through these
kinds of experiences it's the only way
to be an interesting person or going
through these things isn't that big of a
deal because everything turns out okay
in the end anyway now I'm not saying
that those experiences don't have value
because they most certainly do and
they're very real issues for a lot of
people but just speaking of the show
itself 13 reasons why it seems like
almost every time we meet someone who's
actually interesting by their own merits
they just kind of end up being a side
character who only shows up for a brief
moment like Jeff Atkins in season one or
Charley st. George from season three I
think it would have made for a much more
interesting show if for example we've
gotten to know Charlie parallel to
everything else going on you could see
that not every sports jock is Bryce
Walker that if you stopped hanging out
with people who put you in certain
situations your life would be infinitely
less complicated but instead we're just
left with more reminders that the world
is terrible and everyone is suffering
